comments.html: Ericsson used Banyan Vines at least into the late 90s.
comments.name: ghira

comments.html: I remember taking the RSC in October '93.  This was my first exposure to Cisco routers: think AGS+, IGS and IOS 9.1.  By the time we got to CRB/IRB on Thursday afternoon, my brain was ready to pack up!  Lots of fun all round...  :)
comments.name: Robert Larsen

comments.html: It's not live video feeds in financial institutions, the stock ticker itself---along with every other type of imaginable trading-relevant data---is done in IPv4 multicast. Working in the industry, I don't hire anyone that can't at least tell me the difference between SM and DM and what an (S,G) state is.
comments.name: Anon23

comments.html: Working at a SP delivering 3-play we see the complexity of IP multicast is underestimated. Everyone seems to think Multicast is seperate from Unicast. Usually they stop thinking that way when told to fix a RPF failure.
comments.name: Jon

comments.html: I wished I was borned earlier to learn those classic protocols. :-D
comments.name: Yap Chin Hoong

comments.html: I think could be intersting a statistical survey about who is using multicast in his network enviroment..., I work in a broadcast media an we are using multicast for our video distribution in a WAN/LAN scenario and we are very satisfied about it.
comments.name: Christian

comments.html: Ericsson (I like the red touch) should have stuck with it. Certainly they did better job than with any of their IP products.
comments.name: Marko

comments.html:
I would say Multicasting is a far less obscure thing than Banyan Vines.

The financial industry uses it quite a bit and also employs quite a few engineers to keep it all running...
comments.name: Anonymous
